hero.title: We know your day. We've been there.
hero.subtitle: Currico was born from real frustration — from teachers who spent evenings and weekends on lesson prep. We wanted to change that. Not with a big budget, but with heart.

origin.title: How it all started
origin.paragraph1: It started at a kitchen table. Simon came home frustrated from school, talking about how much time he'd spent on worksheets again. Laurent, his friend from the tech world, asked: "Why isn't there a solution for this?"
origin.paragraph2: We talked to other teachers — and heard the same thing everywhere: prep eats up all your free time. Hours spent searching, adapting, designing materials. And even then, it's often not quite what you need.
origin.paragraph3: So we started building something. Not with investors or a grand plan. Just two people who believe teachers deserve tools that give them their time back.
origin.highlight: "Why isn't there a solution for this?" — That one question changed everything.

noticeTakedown.title: 6. Notice and Takedown Procedure
noticeTakedown.content: Currico respects intellectual property rights and responds to proper notices of claimed copyright infringement.

procedure.title: How to Report Copyright Infringement
procedure.content: If you believe that content on Currico infringes your copyright, please send a notice to info@currico.ch containing:

items.identify: Identification of the copyrighted work you claim has been infringed
items.location: The URL or other specific location on Currico where the allegedly infringing material is located
items.contact: Your contact information (name, address, phone number, email)

response.title: Our Response
response.content: Upon receiving a valid notice, Currico will promptly remove or disable access to the allegedly infringing content and notify the seller. Sellers may submit a counter-notice if they believe the takedown was made in error.

introduction.content: Welcome to Currico. By accessing or using our platform, you agree to be bound by these Terms of Service. Currico is a Swiss platform connecting educators to buy, sell, and share high-quality teaching materials aligned with the Swiss curriculum (Lehrplan 21).

items.contract: The purchase contract for teaching materials is concluded directly between the Buyer and the Seller, not with Currico
items.noParty: Currico is not a party to any sales contract and does not become the owner of any teaching materials at any time
items.sellerResponsibility: The Seller is solely responsible for the content, quality, accuracy, and legal compliance of their teaching materials
items.disputes: Any disputes regarding purchased materials must be resolved between Buyer and Seller directly, though Currico may assist in mediation
items.opinion: All uploaded teaching materials represent solely the personal opinion of the respective author. Currico only performs formal review and accepts no liability for the accuracy of the content

items.secure: Keep your password secure and not share your account credentials

faqPage.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faqPage.subtitle: Find answers to the most common questions about Currico

q1.question: What is Currico?
q1.answer: Currico is a Swiss platform where teachers can buy and sell high-quality teaching materials. All materials are specifically designed for the Swiss Lehrplan 21 curriculum and created by experienced teachers.

q2.question: Who is Currico for?
q2.answer: Currico is aimed at all teachers in Switzerland - from primary to secondary level. Our materials are available for Cycle 1, 2, and 3 and cover all subject areas of the Lehrplan 21.

q3.question: Why Currico instead of other platforms?
q3.answer: Currico is 100% focused on Switzerland. All materials use Swiss spelling (ss instead of ß), are aligned with Lehrplan 21, and prices are in Swiss Francs. Additionally, our server is hosted in Switzerland.

q4.question: Do I need to create an account?
q4.answer: You don't need an account to browse and view material previews. However, a free registration is required to buy or sell materials.

q5.question: Is Currico free?
q5.answer: Registration and browsing are free. Free materials can be downloaded at no cost. For paid materials, the listed prices apply. For sellers, the platform fee is 30%.

q6.question: What does Lehrplan 21 mean?
q6.answer: Lehrplan 21 (LP21) is the common curriculum of the German-speaking cantons of Switzerland. It describes the competencies students should acquire during compulsory education, divided into three cycles.

q7.question: How can I contact support?
q7.answer: You can reach us via the contact form on our website or by email at info@currico.ch. We strive to respond to all inquiries within 24 hours.

q1.question: How do I find suitable materials?
q1.answer: Use the search function and filters on the materials page. You can filter by cycle, subject area, dialect (Swiss German/Standard German) and keywords to find exactly the materials you need.

q2.question: What file formats are available?
q2.answer: Most materials are available as PDF and/or Word documents (DOCX). Other formats include PowerPoint (PPTX) and Excel (XLSX). The exact format is indicated for each material.

q3.question: Are the materials editable?
q3.answer: That depends on the file format. Word documents (DOCX) and PowerPoint files (PPTX) are fully editable. PDF files cannot be edited directly but are ideal for printing.

q4.question: How does payment work?
q4.answer: We accept credit cards (Visa, Mastercard), TWINT, and for schools also invoice with QR code. All prices are in Swiss Francs including VAT.

q5.question: Where can I find my purchased materials?
q5.answer: All acquired materials can be found in your Library under 'My Account'. You can re-download the files there at any time.

q6.question: Can I share materials with colleagues?
q6.answer: The license is valid for a single teacher. Sharing with colleagues or uploading to school networks is not permitted. For school licenses, please contact us directly.

q7.question: Can I return materials?
q7.answer: Since these are digital products, returns are generally not possible after download. For technical problems or if the material doesn't match the description, please contact our support.

q8.question: Can I save materials to a wishlist?
q8.answer: Yes, click the heart icon on a material to add it to your wishlist. This way you can bookmark interesting materials for later and easily find them again.

q1.question: How can I sell materials?
q1.answer: Register, go to 'Upload Material', fill in the information, upload your file, and confirm the legal requirements. After publishing, your material is immediately available in the shop.

q2.question: What is the commission rate?
q2.answer: Currico keeps 30% of the sale price as a platform fee. You receive 70% of each sale. For a price of CHF 10.00, you would receive CHF 7.00 per sale.

q3.question: When will I receive my payout?
q3.answer: Payouts are processed automatically via Stripe once your balance reaches CHF 50. The transfer to your bank account usually takes 2-3 business days.

q4.question: What can I upload and what not?
q4.answer: You may only upload self-created materials or content with CC0 license. No scans from textbooks, no protected trademarks or characters, and no copyrighted third-party content. Our Copyright Guide explains all the details.

q5.question: What does LP21-compliant mean?
q5.answer: LP21-compliant means your material is aligned with the competencies of the Lehrplan 21. When uploading, you can select the cycle, subject area, and the corresponding competency codes (e.g., MA.1.A.1).

q6.question: Do I have to use Swiss spelling?
q6.answer: Yes, Swiss spelling is required for German-language materials - that means 'ss' instead of 'ß'. Our upload assistant automatically checks for Eszett characters and offers automatic correction.

q7.question: Can I offer free materials?
q7.answer: Yes, you can also offer materials for free. Free materials often reach more users and help build your reputation as an author. You can change the price at any time.

q8.question: Can I edit my materials after publishing?
q8.answer: Yes, you can edit the title, description, and price of your published materials at any time in your account under 'My Uploads'.

q1.question: How do I download purchased materials?
q1.answer: After purchase, you'll find all acquired materials in your Library under 'My Account'. Click the download button next to the material to download the file.

q2.question: I'm having download problems. What should I do?
q2.answer: First try reloading the page or using a different browser. Also check if your browser is blocking downloads (pop-up blocker). If the problem persists, please contact our support.

q3.question: What file size is allowed for uploads?
q3.answer: The maximum file size is 50 MB per file. Supported formats are PDF, Word (DOCX), PowerPoint (PPTX), and Excel (XLSX). Preview images (PNG, JPG) may be up to 5 MB.

q4.question: Is my data secure?
q4.answer: Yes, we take data protection very seriously. Our servers are located in Switzerland at Infomaniak, and we strictly comply with Swiss data protection law (nDSG) as well as GDPR.

q5.question: Which browsers are supported?
q5.answer: Currico works with all modern browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. We recommend always using the latest version of your browser.

q6.question: Does Currico work on mobile devices?
q6.answer: Yes, Currico is fully responsive and works on smartphones and tablets. You can browse and purchase materials on any device. However, for editing Word documents, we recommend using a computer.

q7.question: My upload failed. What can I do?
q7.answer: Check if your file has the correct format (PDF, DOCX, PPTX, XLSX) and doesn't exceed the maximum size of 50 MB. If you were logged out, log in again and try once more.

copyrightGuide.title: Copyright Guide for Teachers
copyrightGuide.subtitle: Everything you need to know before uploading materials on Currico.
copyrightGuide.intro: This guide helps you understand which materials you can sell on Currico and what to look out for. We want you to feel confident — so we explain the key rules clearly and practically.

legalBasis.title: Legal Basis
legalBasis.description: The Swiss Copyright Act (URG) protects works from the moment of their creation. This means: every worksheet, every photo, and every text is automatically protected — even without a © symbol.

schulprivileg.title: Educational Exception (Art. 19 URG)
schulprivileg.content: Swiss law allows teachers to copy and use copyrighted works in the classroom for direct teaching purposes. This «educational exception» (Schulprivileg) applies only to direct classroom use — not to selling on a platform like Currico.

legalBasis.important: Important: Once you sell materials, the personal use exceptions (Art. 19 URG) no longer apply. You need full usage rights for everything you upload.
legalBasis.reference: Source: Swiss Federal Act on Copyright and Related Rights (URG, SR 231.1)

allowed.title: What can I sell?
allowed.description: You can safely offer these materials on Currico:

items.ownWorksheets: Your own worksheets and teaching materials that you created yourself
items.ownPhotos: Your own photos and self-created illustrations
items.cc0Materials: Materials with CC0 license (Public Domain) — free to use
items.ownPresentations: Your own presentations and learning games

notAllowed.title: What can I NOT sell?
notAllowed.description: These materials must not be uploaded to Currico:

items.textbookScans: Scanned or copied pages from textbooks and school books
items.copyrightedCharacters: Materials with protected characters (Disney, Pixar, Marvel, etc.)
items.copyrightedImages: Images from Google Image Search or social media without a license
items.eszettContent: Materials with Eszett (ß) — in Switzerland we use «ss»
items.thirdPartyContent: Texts or exercises from other textbooks, even if rephrased

ccLicenses.title: Understanding Creative Commons Licenses
ccLicenses.description: Not all «free» licenses allow commercial sale. Here's an overview:

allowed.title: Allowed on Currico
allowed.cc0: CC0 (Public Domain) — No restrictions, free to use
allowed.ccBy: CC-BY (Attribution) — Allowed if you credit the creator
allowed.ccBySa: CC-BY-SA (Attribution, Share Alike) — Allowed with attribution, your material must use the same license

notAllowed.title: NOT allowed on Currico
notAllowed.ccByNd: CC-BY-ND (No Derivatives) — May not be modified or incorporated into your own materials
notAllowed.ccByNcSa: CC-BY-NC-SA — Combination: No selling and same license required

ccLicenses.tip: Tip: Check the exact license for every CC material. Look for «NC» (Non-Commercial) — if it's included, you cannot sell the material.

aiContent.title: AI-Generated Content
aiContent.description: Many teachers use AI tools like ChatGPT, DALL-E, or Midjourney for teaching materials. Here are the rules:

allowedItems.aiText: AI-generated texts that you have substantially revised and adapted
allowedItems.aiInspiration: AI as inspiration for your own designs (e.g. exercise ideas that you develop yourself)
allowedItems.aiLayout: AI-assisted layouts that you designed yourself

cautionItems.aiImages: AI-generated images (Midjourney, DALL-E) — check the terms of use of the respective provider
cautionItems.aiFullContent: Fully AI-generated content without your own revision — legal situation still unclear

notAllowedItems.aiCopy: AI outputs that are recognizably based on copyrighted sources
notAllowedItems.aiStyle: AI images in the style of a specific artist (e.g. «in the style of Miyazaki»)

aiContent.notice: Note: The legal situation regarding AI-generated content is continuously evolving. We recommend using AI as a tool and always substantially editing the results.

images.title: Images: What's allowed?
images.description: Images are a common stumbling block. Here's a clear overview:

allowedItems.cc0Images: CC0 images from sites like Unsplash, Pixabay or Pexels
allowedItems.purchasedStock: Purchased stock photos with commercial license

notAllowedItems.socialMedia: Screenshots from social media or websites
notAllowedItems.editorialStock: Stock photos with «editorial use only» license

imageSources.title: Where to find allowed images
imageSources.description: These sources offer images you can use commercially:

sources.pixabay: Pixabay — Photos, illustrations and vectors, free
sources.pexels: Pexels — Free photos with generous license
sources.openclipart: Openclipart — Public domain clipart for worksheets
sources.wikimediaCommons: Wikimedia Commons — Check the specific license (often CC-BY or CC-BY-SA)

imageSources.tip: Tip: Save the source and license for every image you use. This way you can prove you have the rights if questions arise.

fonts.title: Fonts
fonts.description: Font choice can also be relevant from a copyright perspective:

items.googleFonts: Google Fonts — free and usable, even commercially
items.purchasedFonts: Purchased fonts with commercial license (check the license!)
items.systemFonts: System fonts (Arial, Times New Roman, etc.) — generally allowed
items.freeWithLicense: Free fonts with SIL Open Font License (e.g. from Font Squirrel)

fonts.warning: Note: Some free fonts do not allow commercial use. Always check the license.

greyAreas.title: Grey Areas — Frequent Questions
greyAreas.description: Not everything is black or white. Here are the most common edge cases:

maps.question: Can I use maps from Wikipedia?
maps.answer: It depends on the license. Many Wikipedia maps are CC-BY-SA — you can use them, but you must credit the creator and offer your material under the same license.

exerciseReference.question: Can I reference a textbook exercise without copying it?
exerciseReference.answer: Yes. You may write «Solve exercise 3 on page 42 in the Zahlenbuch». What you cannot do: type out or scan the exercise itself.

historicalImages.question: Are historical images automatically free?
historicalImages.answer: Not necessarily. In Switzerland, copyright protection expires 70 years after the creator's death. Photos from before 1900 are usually free, but check when in doubt.

studentWork.question: Can I use student work as examples?
studentWork.answer: Only with written consent from the parents/guardians. Fully anonymize the work.

schoolLogo.question: Can I use my school's logo?
schoolLogo.answer: No. School logos are protected trademarks. Remove all school logos and names from your materials.

commonMistakes.title: Common Mistakes
commonMistakes.description: We unfortunately see these mistakes often — avoid them:

textbookPages.mistake: Scanning pages from the Zahlenbuch or Sprachstarken textbooks
textbookPages.why: «I only took one page» — Even a single page is copyright-protected. The educational exception does not apply to selling.

clipArt.mistake: Inserting clip art from Google Image Search
clipArt.why: «The image was free on the internet» — Google Image Search shows all images regardless of license. Most are protected.

brandedCharacters.mistake: Using Disney, Pixar, or other protected characters
brandedCharacters.why: «It's just decoration» — Even decorative use is a copyright violation. Disney is known for consistently pursuing violations.

pinterestImages.mistake: Using images from Pinterest or Instagram
pinterestImages.why: «There are so many nice images on Pinterest» — Pinterest shows images from other creators. Without a license, you cannot use them commercially.

modifiedContent.mistake: Slightly modifying textbook exercises and claiming them as your own
modifiedContent.why: «I changed the numbers» — A modification does not change the copyright of the original. The basic structure remains protected.

fontAssumption.mistake: Assuming all free fonts can be used commercially
fontAssumption.why: «The font was free» — Many free fonts are licensed for personal use only. Always check the license terms.
